awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Repair, Weld, and Build Metallic Parts with Fill Impact Welding
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader/commercial impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project seeks to develop a welding technology that will improve the repair, joining, and additive manufacturing of metallic parts and features. First applications include material additions to repair gouges and mis-drilled holes during aircraft production and service, both of which represent significant financial opportunities. Repairs to the structural material are not currently permissible in a production environment due to adverse effects of currently available repair methods on base material properties, usually due to extreme temperatures. Aerostructure manufacturers have a strong incentive to minimize the weight of the aircraft structure, often at the significant financial and environmental expense of scrapping a whole panel. Maintenance, repair and overhaul often entails total replacement of damaged components with new ones as improper repairs of critical components can cause catastrophic harm. Replacement of parts is expensive and has long lead times due to high-value, low-volume nature of the aerospace industry. This project will develop an effective restoration method to repair of metallic components, while being agnostic to the material and part geometry. Reclamation of previously unrepairable parts made from materials such as titanium, nickel, and aluminum has a large positive environmental impact.  Additionally, by broadly enabling solid-state joining, this technology will disrupt the welding industry, globally valued at $20 billion. The foundational technology platform, led in the US, will produce new jobs in science, technology and engineering fields while bolstering domestic manufacturing supply chains.

The innovation underpinning this project involves the sequential, tactical, and controlled deposition of metals using explosive welding.  Explosive welding uses coin-sized metallic elements launched to speeds in the range of 300-1000m/s without explosives. While it is known that explosive welding can weld large plates together, the method is not suited to automation or conventional industrial settings. Impact welding will be developed as a fill-welding technique, much like a filler metal in conventional welding, and will use wrought sheet metal as feedstock. Here, electrically vaporized metallic foils will be used as the driver for the fill elements and the research will focus on whether those elements can be launched reproducibly to develop large bond areas and reproducible positioning. The ability to control element shape and orientation during flight and produce an interface that is fully welded are the most high-risk aspects of the technology. Mechanical testing, scanning electron microscopy, and inline process monitoring such as photonic Doppler velocimetry will be performed. This effort will develop a new process-structure-property loop, with the goal of producing parts that are better than those made with a competing technology such as cold spray as measured by total energy consumption, cost, and mechanical properties.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
For impact welding to be a commercially viable manufacturing technique, it must meet a customer’s need, and it must be a reproducible and controllable process that leads to predictable structures and properties of the resulting weld. The research efforts of this Phase 1 SBIR project were directed toward testing these aspects of the impact welding technique with particular emphasis on solving the issue of entrenched unwelded regions found in many of the previously reported research in this field.

An impact welding fixtures was custom-built to launch flat circular metallic disks (flyer), with thickness ranging between 0.5 to 1.5mm and diameters of 6.25mm to 12.5mm to high speeds, greater than 500 m/s within 5 millimeters of travel distance. The flyers impacted target plates placed at fixed relative angles. It was observed, via cross sectional metallography as well as non-destructive evaluation methods of ultrasonic testing and X-ray computed tomography, that for at least one angle of impact a fully welded interface can be obtained. It was demonstrated that aluminum and titanium flyers can be reproducibly welded to copper and aluminum targets for a certain set of parameters. Furthermore, the impact velocity was found to be controllable and repeatable for various input energies from the capacitor bank power system. For example, for 2.0kJ input energy shots, the average peak velocities of the flyer were measured to be 800m/s with a variation of less than 3%. Using the angular impact welding fixture, heterogeneous welds of aluminum-aluminum and aluminum-steel were successfully created and mechanically tested to fail outside the weld region. The aluminum to steel welding results were shared with a customer from the automotive industry. They granted an initial testing project to Applied Impulse Inc. to investigate the process for their potential welding applications. To test the applicability of the process to a real-world application, impact welding was also used to fill holes in aluminum sheets, representing damaged rivet holes in aerospace aluminum components.  A procedure consisting of preparation, welding, machining and mechanical testing was followed. While the “damaged” coupon had a 66% strength as compared to the reference coupon, the repaired coupons were found to be within 95% of the reference strength without any increase in thickness of the coupon. This improvement in strength was shown repeatedly in testing.

This Phase 1 SBIR grant, and a supplemental award also afforded the project team the opportunities to attend the NSF Bootcamp and the national I-corps programs during which 129 customers and industry stakeholders were interviewed. A major lesson learned from the I-corps program was that one of the stakeholders hypothesized as a customer at the beginning of the program will, in practice, be a key partner in testing and eventually taking the product to the beachhead customer.  Besides passing the component strength criteria, fitting the equipment within a certain weight, size and power limits turned out to be a valuable decision metric for the validated customer segments.  

This Phase 1 effort has proven that impact welding can reproducibly create fully welded interfaces, which are stronger or as strong as the base metal. Moreover, the project team is now more familiar with the equipment requirements and the technical data package needed for assessment and adoption by the potential beachhead customer.

 


Last Modified: 01/24/2025
Modified by: Anupam Vivek

por.por_txt_cntn:
For impact welding to be a commercially viable manufacturing technique, it must meet a customers need, and it must be a reproducible and controllable process that leads to predictable structures and properties of the resulting weld. The research efforts of this Phase 1 SBIR project were directed toward testing these aspects of the impact welding technique with particular emphasis on solving the issue of entrenched unwelded regions found in many of the previously reported research in this field.


An impact welding fixtures was custom-built to launch flat circular metallic disks (flyer), with thickness ranging between 0.5 to 1.5mm and diameters of 6.25mm to 12.5mm to high speeds, greater than 500 m/s within 5 millimeters of travel distance. The flyers impacted target plates placed at fixed relative angles. A procedure consisting of preparation, welding, machining and mechanical testing was followed. While the damaged coupon had a 66% strength as compared to the reference coupon, the repaired coupons were found to be within 95% of the reference strength without any increase in thickness of the coupon. This Phase 1 SBIR grant, and a supplemental award also afforded the project team the opportunities to attend the NSF Bootcamp and the national I-corps programs during which 129 customers and industry stakeholders were interviewed. Moreover, the project team is now more familiar with the equipment requirements and the technical data package needed for assessment and adoption by the potential beachhead customer.
